error.signature: Error from server (Forbidden): pods is forbidden: User cannot perform this action

verdict.summary: RBAC permissions insufficient for the requested action. The user or service account needs a Role/ClusterRole binding.

dead_ends.action: Granting cluster-admin to all service accounts
dead_ends.why_fails: Massive security risk; any pod can do anything in the cluster

workarounds.action: Create a Role with the specific verbs and resources needed
workarounds.how:
kubectl create role pod-reader --verb=get,list,watch --resource=pods -n my-namespace
kubectl create rolebinding pod-reader-binding --role=pod-reader --serviceaccount=my-namespace:my-sa -n my-namespace

workarounds.action: Bind a ClusterRole or Role to the service account
workarounds.how:
# For namespace-scoped access:
kubectl create rolebinding my-binding \
  --clusterrole=view \
  --serviceaccount=default:my-sa \
  -n my-namespace

# For cluster-wide access:
kubectl create clusterrolebinding my-binding \
  --clusterrole=view \
  --serviceaccount=default:my-sa

# Use built-in ClusterRoles: view (read-only), edit (read-write), admin (full namespace access).

workarounds.action: Use kubectl auth can-i to test permissions before applying
workarounds.how:
# Test if current user can perform an action:
kubectl auth can-i create pods -n my-namespace

# Test as a specific service account:
kubectl auth can-i list deployments --as=system:serviceaccount:default:my-sa

# List all permissions for a service account:
kubectl auth can-i --list --as=system:serviceaccount:default:my-sa

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Both are RBAC errors. forbidden_k8s1-linux covers general Forbidden errors; forbidden-user_k8s128-linux focuses on specific user/serviceaccount identity issues.
